ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I am grateful for Professor Jordn's innovative pedagogical approach. She instilled in me a newfound desire to approach historical texts through both a critical and a creative lens. This lesson, among many others, has vastly improved my abilities as a reader, writer, and thinker.
Analytical thinking, section/seminar dialogue engagement, research paper writing,
I learned Spanish history in a way unlike ever before.

I definitely learned how to become a better history student in this course. Although this class was a departmental seminar, Professor Jordan personally guided each and every one of us through the process of historical research, writing, and analysis. The weekly blog post assignments led us to critically synthesize and analyze large quantities of complex information, and our weekly discussions encouraged me to think more deeply about each essay and historical event we studied in order to question and attempt to fill the gaps in our knowledge. I have taken multiple history courses at Yale, but Professor Jordan actively worked to make me a better history student unlike any instructor I have encountered thus far at the university.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Mara is an amazing and kind professor who really cares about what she is teaching and her students.

The strengths of this course were its personable nature and its dedication to building better history students and analyses. This class is not interested in easy fixes; it steadily built on our knowledge and skills each week toward the ultimate goal of our final essay assignment. We had nuanced and critical discussions each week, questioning the veracity of our sources, attempting to fill the gaps in complex narratives, and turning to a variety of sources, including creative works, in an attempt to gain a deep understanding of the time and place which we were studying. The weakness of this course was that, occasionally, our deadlines weren't always clear, leading to some confusion among our class regarding when to turn in assignments.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Zoom can surprise you. Although I never met any of my seminar classmates in-person, the bond and rapport we were able to build each discussion section was amazing and engaging. I regret that we were not able to sit in the same classroom every week, but I am grateful for how seamless this class transitioned to Zoom.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I already have recommended this course to many of my friends and colleagues!
Would highly recommend this course if youre interested in Spanish history. If not, Id still recommend because Professor Jordan is truly one of the best professors Ive had at Yale.

Absolutely. Professor Jordan is an extremely kind and engaging seminar leader. The thematic organization of the course is wonderful and gives you insights not only on 15th and 16th century Spain but also on contemporary conversations in Europe about race, indigenous rights, poor assistance, and veiling for Muslim women.
Yes, if they are interested in learning about Spanish history.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student! Professor Jordan is one of the best instructors I've ever had at Yale, and her course provided telling insight into a complex yet critical period and place in history. Our discussions were one of the highlights of an otherwise difficult Zoom semester. Moreover, Professor Jordan goes out of her way to support and encourage her students. The frequent emails she sent to our class, as well as the multiple meetings I had with her about the subject material and my final paper, kept our class constantly engaged and helped me become a better history student. You must take at least one course with Professor Jordan during your time at Yale.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had a weekly virtual seminar.
